thread.title: Austin Macias earns Burlington Central's first state wrestling title
thread.title_full: Austin Macias earns Burlington Central's first state wrestling title

author: Steve Millar
title: Austin Macias earns Burlington Central's first state wrestling title
text:
Austin Macias earns Burlington Central's first state wrestling title Austin Macias earns Burlington Central’s first state wrestling title Brian O'Mahoney / The Courier-News Burlington Central's Austin Macias, right, rallied for a 10-7 win in the Class 2A 126-pound state final on Saturday. Burlington Central's Austin Macias, right, rallied for a 10-7 win in the Class 2A 126-pound state final on Saturday. (Brian O'Mahoney / The Courier-News) Steve Millar Elgin Courier-News Privacy Policy 
CHAMPAIGN — Burlington Central junior Austin Macias said he considered transferring to Montini, which several of his friends attend. 
One thing, though, convinced him to stay with the Rockets: the opportunity to become the school's first state champion wrestler. 
"I wanted to be that kid on the wall that everybody wanted to be," Macias said. "That's the reason I stayed." 
Macias made his dream come true Saturday, rallying for a 10-7 win over returning champ Tyler Delaware of downstate Washington to capture the Class 2A 126-pound final at State Farm Center. 
"Part of me wanted to (leave for Montini)," Macias said. "I'm a hometown kid, though. I've always lived in Burlington. I decided this is where I wanted to be and this is what I wanted to do to make my town proud." 
Macias (36-2) lost to Delaware (33-7) — who won the 2A 120-pound title last year — in the championship match of the Sterling Sectional. The rematch seemed to be headed in a similar direction when Delaware jumped out to a 5-1 lead. 
Macias, though, was still confident. 
"I just felt like I couldn't lose," he said. "When I was down, I didn't care. I knew he couldn't stop me on my feet. I started taking it to him. I was getting in on my shots. I was feeling it. I just knew it." 
Macias took control in the final period, sealing the win with a late takedown. 
"I'm that kid that I wanted to be now," he said. "I've got to be even better next year and get another title." 
Macias' teammate, Nick Termini (40-5), took home a medal with a sixth-place finish at 132. 
In Class 3A, Huntley freshman David Ferrante finished fourth at 152. 
Ferrante (29-4) advanced to the semifinals before being pinned by St. Rita's Austin O'Connor, who went on to become a four-time state champion. 
He battled back to beat Montini's Matt Ortiz 8-4 in the semifinal wrestlebacks before a 4-2 overtime loss to Marmion's Brad Gross in the third-place match. 
"After the match (against O'Connor), I had my mind set on coming back strong (Saturday)," Ferrante said. "It's been a great run. I'd like to thank my coaches, my family, my friends and my teammates for pushing me." 
It's been a memorable year for Ferrante and Huntley, which will take on Wheeling in Tuesday's team sectional at Rockford East. 
"The team has had a lot of firsts this year," Ferrante said. "First Fox Valley championship, first regional championship, most state qualifiers. Just to be a part of that is really awesome, especially as a freshman." 
Dundee-Crown senior Chase Raap came home from his first state meet with a medal, finishing sixth at 182. 
Raap (43-11) pulled off a dramatic 4-2 overtime win over Prospect's Alex Kozcwara in the quarterfinal wrestlebacks to clinch the medal. 
"I'm definitely proud," he said. "It was my goal just to make it to state, then I made it the goal to get a medal. This feels great." 
Steve Millar is a freelance writer for The Courier-News.
